A true miracle. </p><p>For many, the phrase “adult board games” only brings to mind Cards Against Humanity. Below, a few top picks curated using a mixture of personal opinion, the advice of gamer friends and, of course, the fine work of Amazon reviewers. </p><p><strong><a href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008A2BA8G?ie=UTF8&tag=dailybeastpartygames-20&camp=1789&linkCode=xm2&creativeASIN=B008A2BA8G">The Resistance</a>, $10.83 on Amazon</strong></p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/try-these-board-games-featuring-corrupt-governments-and-monocle-wearing-dogs?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/AmNPl2N0PGA" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/AmNPl2N0PGA/try-these-board-games-featuring-corrupt-governments-and-monocle-wearing-dogs</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/try-these-board-games-featuring-corrupt-governments-and-monocle-wearing-dogs?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By Shelby Lorman]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 15:22:36 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/try-these-board-games-featuring-corrupt-governments-and-monocle-wearing-dogs?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[Why Bitcoin Is Still Worth Investing In]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518964705/bitcoin_rwa2mp"></figure><p>You may have heard more people recently both celebrate and bemoan the state of the cryptocurrency market, especially the explosive rise and fall (and most recently, rise again) of Bitcoin. Even if you only have a layman's knowledge of how the cryptocurrency market tends to fare, you've probably walked away with the obvious impression: yes, it's volatile. Even though Bitcoin dropped below $6,000 last week (for investors, that's a hair-pulling 70% less than the value of its all-time high in December), it's since played a comeback kid move, surging up by 50% and topping $9,000 as of this last weekend. Investors have experienced a roller coaster ride that shows no signs of slowing down just quite yet. The current state of Bitcoin is on the up and up, and while no one can quite explain why, it’s a great time to <a href="https://shop.thedailybeast.com/sales/the-bitcoin-cryptocurrency-master-bundle?utm_source=thedailybeast.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=the-bitcoin-cryptocurrency-master-bundle&utm_term=scsf-271667&utm_content=a0x1a000003b7A6&scsonar=1">educate yourself on how it all works</a>. </p><p>So is it still a good time to invest in and learn about cryptocurrencies? The short answer is, yes. The fact of the matter is, cryptocurrencies are utterly dependent on the ever-changing whims of the market, meaning they'll rise and fall based on how urgently the market believes in their investment. And while the dips can cause a bit of a panic, Bitcoin's performance speaks for itself: it's outdone any asset or stock you might have otherwise invested in. </p><p>Here's the big note: don't invest any amount you can't stand to lose. Be sure that whatever you put into Bitcoin is not essential to your daily life and operations. And despite the valleys and the peaks, long-term investors in Bitcoin indeed have something to show for it: for example, if you had invested $1,000 in Bitcoin in 2011, you would have $36.7 million now. To successfully invest in Bitcoin, it's important to stay true to the most basic tenets of investment: start small, play the market wisely and patiently and you could end up with some big wins. </p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/why-bitcoin-is-still-worth-investing-in?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/fPIP_vtb8cc" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/fPIP_vtb8cc/why-bitcoin-is-still-worth-investing-in</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/why-bitcoin-is-still-worth-investing-in?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By samantha.winkelman@thedailybeast.com (Samantha Winkelman)]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 14:38:43 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/why-bitcoin-is-still-worth-investing-in?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[Mixing Up the Paris of the 1920s]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518909832/180216-rothbaum-paris-bars-tease-1_mj9m3j"><figcaption>Getty</figcaption></figure><p>When work is relentless and overwhelming (yes, even drinks writers get stretches of that, in between the cocktail-sipping, the rare whisky-judging and the tax-deductible wallowing in low and decrepit dives that just happen to have excellent jukeboxes); when the news, all mendacity and greed and cold-eyed slaughter, is one emotional hand-grenade after another, lobbed straight into your foxhole; when everything is grim and grey and galling, I like to send my mind on vacation.</p><p>Now, sensible souls, when they do such a thing, direct their thoughts to times and places they have been happy. They’ll think of that perfect personal day, the beach vacation, the candlelit date, the little restaurant in Barcelona, the Springsteen concert, the night their team came back from behind to win it all. I tend to send my mind somewhat farther back, to places it has never experienced in person.</p><p>Say, like Republican Rome under the Consulate of Cicero, where I could sip Falernian wine and listen to Lucretius recite atomic theory hammered into verses of fire or be by turns charmed, beguiled and stricken with pathos by Catullus’s matchless lyrics. Or Restoration London, where I could sit in the corner of Will’s Coffee House drinking Rack Punch and listening to John Dryden and his fellow wits bat the words around like shuttlecocks.</p><p><a src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518914571/180209-mills-willa-cather-hero_cmbxle"><figcaption>Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast</figcaption></figure><p>This year<a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/american-dreams-o-pioneers-by-willa-cather"> Willa Cather’s</a> early masterpiece, <a href="https://www.amazon.com/My-%C3%81ntonia-Dover-Thrift-Editions/dp/0486282406/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1517959202&sr=1-3&keywords=my+antonia"><em>My Antonia</em></a>, turns 100, but these days, thanks to the most explosive<a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-immigration-standoff-between-trump-and-schumer-is-likely-to-end-in-a-fail-safe-punt"> immigration crisis</a> in American life since the Reagan era’s Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 passed Congress, <em>My Antonia</em> has acquired a new timeliness.</p><p>At the center of <em>My Antonia</em> lies the Dreamer-like story of Antonia Shimerda Cuzak, a Bohemian immigrant who at age 14 comes with her family to the Nebraska of the 1880s and adapts to life in the West with a completeness unmatched by her American-born neighbors. Antonia’s story is told by Jim Burden, who arrives in Nebraska the same day that she does to live with his grandparents after his own parents have died.</p><p>Jim, who has been living in Virginia, must, like Antonia, adjust to the challenges of a Nebraska that is new to him, but his grandparents are kind, prosperous people. The hardships that are Antonia’s are not his. Jim does not have to worry about where his next meal is coming from or how he will get through the cold, Nebraska winters. The difference in the paths that have been laid out for Jim and Antonia, who is four years older than he, is spelled out early in the novel when Antonia says to him, “Things will be easy for you. But they will be hard for us.”</p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/willa-cather-nailed-the-immigrant-ideal-we-should-cherish?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/l3kS82H9VOI" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/l3kS82H9VOI/willa-cather-nailed-the-immigrant-ideal-we-should-cherish</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/willa-cather-nailed-the-immigrant-ideal-we-should-cherish?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By Nicolaus Mills]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 02:28:12 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/willa-cather-nailed-the-immigrant-ideal-we-should-cherish?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[She Wrote a Novel About Nuclear Terror—Could It Come True?]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518914699/180217-Beard-Nuclear-terror-hero_kzvenx"><figcaption>Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast</figcaption></figure><p>I never wanted my new novel to be timely. When I began researching the book that would become <em><a href="https://www.amazon.com/dp/0062666711?_encoding=UTF8&isInIframe=0&n=283155&ref_=dp_proddesc_0&s=books&showDetailProductDesc=1#product-description_feature_div">The Atomic City Girls</a></em>, I wanted to write about the making of the first atomic bomb—specifically, the thousands of everyday people who came to Oak Ridge, Tennessee to work in top-secret facilities built to enrich uranium.</p><p>Most of the workers had no idea of the purpose of their jobs until the bomb they had helped to create was dropped on<a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/obama-calls-to-end-nukes-at-hiroshima"> Hiroshima</a>, forcing them to grapple with the moral questions raised by this world-changing event. I thought I was writing about a subject that was safely historical.</p><p>But at the end of January, the <em>Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists </em>moved its famous<a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-doomsday-clock-just-moved-forward-30-seconds"> Doomsday Clock</a> to two minutes to midnight—their direst assessment of the proximity of global catastrophe since 1953. Suddenly, we are all being forced to think about the questions haunting my fictional characters in a more real and terrifying way than we have in a long time.</p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/she-wrote-a-novel-about-nuclear-terrorcould-it-come-true?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/znEjxUCNwrY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/znEjxUCNwrY/she-wrote-a-novel-about-nuclear-terrorcould-it-come-true</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/she-wrote-a-novel-about-nuclear-terrorcould-it-come-true?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By Janet Beard]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 02:27:52 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/she-wrote-a-novel-about-nuclear-terrorcould-it-come-true?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[Trump's Infrastructure Plan Is Bigly Biased Against Cities]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518908160/180216-Gelinas-trump-infrastructure-tease_cbr2pl"><figcaption>Adrees Latif/Reuters</figcaption></figure><p>President Trump's <a href="https://www.scribd.com/document/371349339/White-House-infrastructure-plan#fullscreen&from_embed">infrastructure plan</a>, released Monday, is more of a defiance of fiscal logic than it is a rational outline. One obvious shortcoming is that the plan doesn't offer states and cities federal money as much as invite them to spend their own, which, of course, they could already do.</p><p>Perhaps the biggest drawback, though, is that the plan pits urban and rural areas against each other when it comes to the small amount of money it does offer. All of America needs investment, but the plan's blatant prejudice against cities would only widen the nation's political and cultural animosities.</p><p>Trump has disappointed in many ways, but this failure is an acute letdown. In the mid-1980s, Trump scored one of his early p.r. coups with a modest New York City infrastructure triumph, finishing a Central Park skating rink after the city had failed. In 2016, he ran heavily on the issue – and implied that he'd apply his supposed building expertise to his hometown. “We have the old Long Island Rail Road,” <a href="https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2016/04/17/trump_im_so_happy_china_is_upset_with_me.html">he said</a> at one fundraiser, “like we're a third-world country. They have trains that go 250 mph, we have old stuff,” he continued, referring to China. “That's not going to happen anymore with me.”</p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-infrastructure-plan-is-insanely-biased-against-cities?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/sWSI0JSVejM" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/sWSI0JSVejM/trump-infrastructure-plan-is-insanely-biased-against-cities</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-infrastructure-plan-is-insanely-biased-against-cities?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By Nicole Gelinas]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 02:25:57 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-infrastructure-plan-is-insanely-biased-against-cities?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[Robotic Gunner Screened Human Soldiers in U.S. Army War Game]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518920662/180211-axe-robot-lede_jyp7ma"><figcaption>Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast</figcaption></figure><p>A machine-gun-armed robotic armored vehicle provided covering fire for U.S. Army soldiers during a summer 2017 war game, a top Army official said.</p><p>The robotic fire support, part of the Army's Northern Strike exercise in Michigan in late July and early August, could signal a profound shift in the ground-combat branch's acceptance of armed robots.</p><p>Back in 2008, the Army <a href="https://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/gadgets/a2804/4258963/">sidelined</a> an earlier model of armed robot that it had deployed to Iraq amid rumors that the 'bot might erratically aim its machine gun. Nine years later, officials finally allowed a similar automaton to fire in close proximity to U.S. troops during a realistic training exercise.</p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/robotic-gunner-screened-human-soldiers-in-us-army-war-game?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/R8SBslW3fY4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/R8SBslW3fY4/robotic-gunner-screened-human-soldiers-in-us-army-war-game</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/robotic-gunner-screened-human-soldiers-in-us-army-war-game?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By David Axe]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 02:24:49 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/robotic-gunner-screened-human-soldiers-in-us-army-war-game?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[The Revealing Ghosts of Robert F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr.]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518908016/180218-Freedlander-Robert-Kennedy-hero__jajbay"><figcaption>Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast</figcaption></figure><p>For most of their public lives, <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/bobby-kennedy-uniquely-blended-ruthlessness-and-compassion">Robert F. Kennedy</a> and <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-march-dr-martin-luther-king-jr-never-got-to-see">Martin Luther King, Jr.</a> were hardly allies, let alone friends. The dividing line was too thick, one the heir of Irish-American royalty, the other the agitator for civil rights in the Deep South. And there is scant record of their lives touching.</p><p>Yet both men, who died fifty years ago this year, are the subject of a slender new show at the New York Historical Society called <a href="http://www.nyhistory.org/exhibitions/rebel-spirits-robert-f-kennedy-and-martin-luther-king-jr">Rebel Spirits: Robert F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King, Jr</a>.</p><p>Because the record of their relationship is so slight, one that transpired mostly over phone calls, the exhibition is in part not so much the story of two charismatic American icons as it is the story, told largely through sixty news photographs, of the civil rights movement in America and its often uneasy relationship to power. </p><p><a She was just making a joke, a pun, a funny aside, really, when she said that Cavaliers basketball player LeBron James should just “shut up and dribble.” She was offended when he said in a video that President Donald Trump “doesn’t understand the people, and really don’t give a f--- about the people.” </p><p>She could have apologized in that non-apologetic way famous people have of being sorry in the off-chance someone was offended. But why do that when you’ve got a made-for-TV ratings hit? There’s James, whom she went after for trying to go pro a year early, and for his "barely intelligible, not to mention ungrammatical," way of speaking versus a right wing anchor of the sort Fox cloned until its sexual harassment scandal sent it’s most famous scurrying for higher ground. </p><p>While James was growing up poor and fatherless to become a successful businessman, model father, and pillar of the community, Ingraham was becoming rich and famous by way of Dartmouth College where she was known for hunting and bagging liberals as an editor at the conservative Dartmouth Review. She regretted that publicly when she found out many years later that her brother was dying from AIDs, as if treating a gay person properly was possible only if you had one in the family. Ultimately, of course, another 19 will fall short of the final prize. There can only be one.</p><p>Don’t be fooled into thinking this exercise reflects on how tech savvy these cities are, though. In our work we’ve crisscrossed the country, evaluating and writing about local government innovation in municipalities large and small. We’ve found hundreds of effective new programs and initiatives. </p><p>In Pittsburgh’s Allegheny County, for instance, when a family services caseworker enters a home in response to a call alleging abuse to meet with an often emotional, sometimes angry, family, she arrives with a tablet connected to information on the client’s history of involvement with the child welfare, mental health, and criminal justice systems. Back at the office, she gets alerts about critical changes in the household such as a new violent crime offense. </p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/to-join-the-tech-revolution-cities-need-a-new-operating-system?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/EoQmFgDLDyQ" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/EoQmFgDLDyQ/to-join-the-tech-revolution-cities-need-a-new-operating-system</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/to-join-the-tech-revolution-cities-need-a-new-operating-system?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By Stephen Goldsmith Neil Kleiman]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 17:49:37 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/to-join-the-tech-revolution-cities-need-a-new-operating-system?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[Miracles on Ice: Nathan Chen & Adam Rippon Miss the Podium, But Make Olympic History]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518883914/180217-Fallon-Men-Figure-Skaters-hero_guck8k"><figcaption>Getty</figcaption></figure><p>The American male figure skaters—<a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/figure-skater-brains-are-literally-wired-differently">Nathan Chen</a>, <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/thanks-mike-pence-you-helped-make-adam-rippon-an-lgbtq-olympics-hero">Adam Rippon</a>, and <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/us-figure-skater-vincent-zhou-lands-historic-quadruple-lutz">Vincent Zhou</a>—have each made history. So breathless and astonished are we over the skills and star power they exhibited, in fact, that we almost forget that they completely miffed it at <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/keyword/2018-winter-olympics">the Olympics</a>. </p><p>Yes, for the second Olympics in a row, not a single American man medaled in figure skating. But boy does that not seem to matter, with the Holy Trinity of ice gods throwing up bonafide miracles, both <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/adam-rippon-needs-to-host-snl-immediately">on the ice and off</a></p><p>From the ashes of their failed Olympic bids—Chen finished 5th, Zhou 6th, and Rippon 10th—rose these bodysuit-wearing phoenixes, icons of resilience, quad jumps, and sass, respectively changing the way we armchair critics at home see skating, sports, sexuality, masculinity, and patriotism. Medals be damned.</p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/miracles-on-ice-nathan-chen-and-adam-rippon-miss-the-podium-but-make-olympic-history?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/S-6QP4snANI" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/S-6QP4snANI/miracles-on-ice-nathan-chen-and-adam-rippon-miss-the-podium-but-make-olympic-history</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/miracles-on-ice-nathan-chen-and-adam-rippon-miss-the-podium-but-make-olympic-history?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By kevin.fallon@thedailybeast.com (Kevin Fallon)]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 16:13:03 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/miracles-on-ice-nathan-chen-and-adam-rippon-miss-the-podium-but-make-olympic-history?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[A President’s Day Without a Real President]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_1440,w_2560,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518880244/180217-Reid-presidents-day-hero_us2t3b"><figcaption>Mandel Ngan /Getty Images</figcaption></figure><p>Monday is President’s Day. It will be the second consecutive such holiday without an American president. Sure, Donald Trump sits in the Oval Office, when he’s not golfing. He lives in the White House, at least in theory with his family. But he is not the president of the United States. </p><p>When Trump addressed the nation in the wake of the Parkland massacre, my team and I looked at the TV but the words coming from his mouth had no effect. They neither resonated nor moved a single person in the room. It truly didn’t matter what he said, particularly after he tweeted out blame for the carnage at the neighbors and classmates of the killer. Trump is as hollow a vessel as there has ever been in the White House. His rule lacks even a shred of moral authority.</p><p>Meanwhile, an indictment of 13 Russian nationals by the Robert Mueller grand jury on Friday reinforced what we already know, Vladimir Putin’s cronies launched a widespread, aggressive and ultimately successful influence operation aimed at the U.S. presidential election of 2016 with the goal of dragging down Hillary Clinton and electing Trump. The campaign included encouraging Bernie Sanders voters and minorities to stay home or vote for General Michael Flynn’s fellow American dinner guest of RT and Putin at that now-infamous paid dinner, Jill Stein, but its intent was clear: support Trump by every available means.</p><p><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/a-presidents-day-without-a-real-president?source=articles_sum&via=rss">Read more at The Daily Beast.</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~4/KaJvB1Ol-40" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/thedailybeast/articles/~3/KaJvB1Ol-40/a-presidents-day-without-a-real-president</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.thedailybeast.com/a-presidents-day-without-a-real-president?source=articles_sum&via=rss</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[By Joy-Ann Reid]]></dc:creator><pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 15:11:27 GMT</pubDate><feedburner:origLink>https://www.thedailybeast.com/a-presidents-day-without-a-real-president?source=articles_sum&via=rss</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title><![CDATA[Russian Troll Factory Alum Selling Social Media Mobs for $299 a Month]]></title><description><figure><img src="https://img.thedailybeast.com/image/upload/c_crop,d_placeholder_euli9k,h_675,w_1200,x_0,y_0/dpr_2.0/c_limit,w_585/fl_lossy,q_auto/v1518825594/180216-poulsen-ira-lede-2_my57kf"></figure><p>Ever wished your personal or corporate Facebook account had the same polish and verve as the legion of fake accounts created by <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/mueller-indicts-trumps-claim-that-russian-interference-is-fake-news?ref=home">Russia’s election trolls</a>? Then here’s good news. The newly indicted Internet Research Agency, or a former worker at the St. Petersburg troll factory, may be getting into the social media management business.</p><p>Working backwards from information in <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/mueller-indicts-russian-groups-first-revealed-by-daily-beast">Robert Mueller’s new indictment</a>, The Daily Beast discovered a website called YourDigitalFace.com which offers a service eerily similar to the IRA’s specialty: creating and voicing social media accounts under any persona needed. </p><p>For as little as $299 a month, YourDigitalFace will “create your new digital face which sells,” reads the pitch on the site.
